dt: {bc}marked by a lack of interest, {d_link|enthusiasm|enthusiasm}, or concern for something {bc}{sx|apathetic||}
{bc}marked by no special liking for or dislike of something

dt.t: {wi}indifferent{/wi} about which task he was given

dt: {bc}that does not matter one way or the other
{bc}of no importance or value one way or the other
{bc}capable of development in more than one direction

pt: {sc}indifferent{/sc} {sc}unconcerned{/sc} {sc}incurious{/sc} {sc}aloof{/sc} {sc}detached{/sc} {sc}disinterested{/sc} mean not showing or feeling interest. {sc}indifferent{/sc} implies neutrality of attitude from lack of inclination, preference, or prejudice.
{sc}unconcerned{/sc} suggests a lack of sensitivity or regard for others' needs or troubles.
{sc}incurious{/sc} implies an inability to take a normal interest due to dullness of mind or to self-centeredness.
{sc}aloof{/sc} suggests a cool reserve arising from a sense of superiority or disdain for inferiors or from shyness.
{sc}detached{/sc} implies an objective attitude achieved through absence of prejudice or selfishness.
{sc}disinterested{/sc} implies a circumstantial freedom from concern for personal or especially financial advantage that enables one to judge or advise without bias.

pt.t: judged by a panel of {it}disinterested{/it} observers

quotes.t: … aspects of language that the earlier grammarians were {qword}indifferent{/qword} to.
For it is commonly said and commonly believed that science is completely neutral and {qword}indifferent{/qword} as to the ends and values which move men to act …
It can hardly be argued, by himself or by his defenders, that he was {qword}indifferent{/qword} to, or unaware of, the true situation.

et: Middle English, from Anglo-French or Latin; Anglo-French, from Latin {it}indifferent-, indifferens{/it}, from {it}in-{/it} + {it}different-, differens{/it}, present participle of {it}differre{/it} to be different {ma}{mat|differ|}{/ma}
shortdef: marked by a lack of interest, enthusiasm, or concern for something : apathetic
marked by no special liking for or dislike of something
being neither good nor bad : mediocre
